prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: GRB1_Band4
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Observation of first GRB, with the first of the four observations preferentially in the night following the trigger. Obtain 140 GHz total flux for a GRB afterglow (point source).

prj:VisitConstraint.prj:note:
The time of the first visit will be determined by triggering (this is a ToO proposal).
We request 2 epochs to be done as soon as possible after triggering and within the two weeks tolerance accepted in Cycle 2. We only impose the condition that the 2 epochs are observed in different nights. For the other 2 epochs, we request a longer reaction time of 2-3 weeks after triggering. We understand that turn-around faster than 2 weeks is not guaranteed, and we fully accept the risk that the first two visits may not be executed. We emphasize that even the two late-time epochs (i.e. 2-3 weeks after triggering) would still give unique data, as the time evolution at early and late times is coupled.

We request 2 epochs to be done as soon as possible after triggering and within the two weeks tolerance accepted in Cycle 2. We only impose the condition that the 2 epochs are observed in different nights. For the other 2 epochs, we request a longer reaction time of 2-3 weeks after triggering. We understand that turn-around faster than 2 weeks is not guaranteed, and we fully accept the risk that the first two visits may not be executed. We emphasize that even the two late-time epochs (i.e. 2-3 weeks after triggering) would still give unique data, as the time evolution at early and late times is coupled.

We request 2 epochs to be done as soon as possible after triggering and within the two weeks tolerance accepted in Cycle 2. We only impose the condition that the 2 epochs are observed in different nights. For the other 2 epochs, we request a longer reaction time of 2-3 weeks after triggering. We understand that turn-around faster than 2 weeks is not guaranteed, and we fully accept the risk that the first two visits may not be executed. We emphasize that even the two late-time epochs (i.e. 2-3 weeks after triggering) would still give unique data, as the time evolution at early and late times is coupled.

The time of the first visit will be determined by triggering (this is a ToO proposal).
We request 2 epochs to be done as soon as possible after triggering and within the two weeks tolerance accepted in Cycle 2. We only impose the condition that the 2 epochs are observed in different nights. For the other 2 epochs, we request a longer reaction time of 2-3 weeks after triggering. We understand that turn-around faster than 2 weeks is not guaranteed, and we fully accept the risk that the first two visits may not be executed. We emphasize that even the two late-time epochs (i.e. 2-3 weeks after triggering) would still give unique data, as the time evolution at early and late times is coupled.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
The target is a point source, and the position accuracy will be +-1 arcsec upon triggering - therefore the antenna configuration is irrelevant.
The scientifically most rewarding case is an observation during the first 3-4 days after trigger, when simultaneous optical/near-infrared and X-ray data are available. At this time, the source will typically be >0.1 mJy
An observation as late as 20 days after trigger is still scientifically valuable - at that time, we expect a flux of order 0.05 mJy. Our rms requirement of 0.02 mJy shall allow a 3 sigma detection until 20 days after trigger under nominal conditions.
We are interested in the continuums flux. We specified standard settings - we also tolerate non-standard settings if this makes the execution of this ToO easier. Bandpass accuracy is not an issue.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose multi-epoch ToO observations of three GRB afterglows to constrain the spectral energy distribution (SED) in the (sub-)mm. Combined with public X-ray data from Swift, our proprietary and guaranteed optical/NIR (GROND, ESO/La Silla) and radio (ATCA, Australia) data, the multi-epoch SEDs from 5 GHz to 10 keV will allow us to test the theoretically predicted temporal evolution of the SED in the standard afterglow (fireball) scenario. This will enable us to precisely determine the energetics of the burst and to measure the energy partition between electrons and magnetic field. Our detection of the GRB 100621A afterglow with APEX/LABOCA has already demonstrated convincingly the feasibility of our strategy, and the science verification detection of GRB 110715A has demonstrated the rapid (12 hrs) turn-around ToO with ALMA.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:relatedProposals: ESO 89D-0266 / ESO 90D-0842 / ESO 91D-0131: accepted for APEX/LABOCA ESO 92D-0211 accepted for APEX/LABOCA (for period Oct 2013 - Mar 2014)
prp:ObsProposal.prp:previousProposals: 2011.00915.T rejected because rapid turn-around not offered., 2011.0.00915.T 2012.00399.T rejected because rapid turn-around not offered., 2012.1.00399.T
prp:ObsProposal.prp:recentPublications: Greiner J. et al 2009, ApJ 693, 1610 Greiner J. et al 2009, ApJ 693, 1912 Greiner J. et al 2011, A&A 526, A30
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: International Centre for Radio Astronomy Research
Niels Bohr Institute, Copenhagen, University of
